Backgrounding resources

  • IRE Tip Sheet #2529, “Backgrounding People,” Pat Stith, Raleigh News & Observer, 2005
  • IRE Tip Sheet #3358, “Backgrounding People and Businesses,” Jaimi Dowdell, 2010
  • IRE Tip Sheet #4177, Another backgrounding handout from IRE and its companion, The Omaha World Herald's quest for the background of a crime family</a>
  • IRE Tip Sheet #3238, “Ways to Trace Every Business,” Ron Campbell, 2010
  • IRE Tip Sheet #3716, "Uncovering the private parts of public figures", Doug Haddix, 2012
  • Tip sheet from the Stabile reporting program
    • </ul> ### One approach Ask these questions about any person, company or property: * What do they say about themselves? * What do others say about them? * What's missing from both accounts? * What has been mischaracterized (on purpose or by accident)?

    New York resources

    • SeeThroughNY, a public interest group with New York city payroll, pension and contract information obtained through public records
    • The New York City Finance Department site contains property records, including mortgage and deed information. You will probably have to look up the block and lot information using the address lookup to get much information. I've had trouble with the latest Java problems getting the actual documents online.
    • The New York State campaign finance office has searchable contributions
    • Many records require you go to the office to request information: New York voter information is only available online if you know the full name and date of birth of the person you're looking for.
    • New York State e-courts include varying levels of access to criminal, civil, housing, family and other courts.
    • Don't forget about federal records: campaign finance through the Center for Responsive Politics, court cases and bankruptcies through PACER (a pay service that is very inexpensive), and business records from the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, the Small Business Administration and the Environmental Protection Administration. Many of these records are collected by Enigma.io (free but you you have to sign up)
